ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

RENTAL VALUE OF NO. 11 NAPIER ROAD


    1. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Law whether any opinion of the rental value of the property was obtained before the Commissioner of Lands granted a lease for three years in July 1978

Column: 1510

of No. 11 Napier Road to the People's Action Party at a rent of $2,000.00 p.m.

     The Minister for Law (Mr E.W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is yes.

    Prior to the PAP's occupation of No. 11 Napier Road, the building, which was managed by the Ministry of Finance (Revenue Division), was rented out to the Applied Research Corporation at a monthly rental of $2,000. The Commissioner of Lands, in consultation with the

Column: 1511

Ministry of Finance, charged the PAP the same rental of $2,000 per month.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Sir, is the Minister aware or was the Commissioner of Lands aware that in 1978 the property would have fetched a rental value of $4,000 in the market?

     Mr Barker: Sir, I am not aware of the values in the vicinity. The Chief Assessor made the valuation. But perhaps I could help the Member. When the Applied Research Corporation first went into occupation, the building was in a bad state and they had to spend about $72,000 towards repairs and renovations. When the PAP moved in, the PAP reimbursed the Applied Research Corporation $55,000. So, in addition to the rental of $2,000, if you consider this big sum divided by the number of years, it would be another $2,000 per month over a three-year lease.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Sir, the renovations would have been capital expenditure, would they not? Why should they be included in the rental value?

     Mr Barker: Sir, one of the terms of the three-year lease was that at the end of that period the additions, including airconditioners, could not be taken away by the Applied Research Corporation. This term was also applied to the PAP.

SBS BUS FARES
(Request for reduction)


    2. Mr Hwang Soo Jin asked the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour whether, in view of the substantial savings in costs achieved, he will direct the Singapore Bus Service (1978) Limited to consider a reduction in fares.

     The Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour (Mr Ong Teng Cheong): Mr Speaker, Sir, as I explained to the House on 5th March 1982, 1981 was a fortunate year for SBS. The price of diesel did not escalate as much as SBS had feared at the time that fares were increased across-the-board on 1st April, 1981. The weakening of some foreign currencies against the Singapore dollar also contributed to the favourable position by way of cheaper spare parts.

Column: 1512



    At the same time, determined efforts by SBS to cut costs and improve productivity led to more cost savings primarily through more extensive use of OMO services. For these reasons, a second across-the-board fare increase planned for late 1981 was averted. One could argue that this is tantamount to a reduction in fares in real terms. To reduce fares now will almost certainly mean that future increases have to be larger. A more sensible approach would be to intensify the search for cost-saving measures and hope that external factors remain favourable. In this way, future bus fare increases can be kept to the minimum.

Column: 1512

RADIO AND TV LICENCE FEES
(Request for reduction)


    3. Mr Hwang Soo Jin asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Culture whether, in the light of the considerable profits made by the Singapore Broadcasting Corporation during the past year, he will consider a reduction in Radio and TV licence fees.

     The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Culture (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, while it is true that SBC has realized a surplus of $19.3 million during the 14 months of its operation, I do not consider it prudent to reduce the licence fee.

    SBC has achieved the surplus because of improvements which have made the broadcasting service a more attractive advertising and sales media, resulting in an increase in income for SBC. The surplus is to be ploughed back on improvement of SBC's programmes. SBC intends to build up its capability both in facilities and talents in order to increase its own production of programmes, geared specifically to meet our needs and interests. However, production of local programmes is much more expensive than acquisition of programmes from abroad. Therefore, it is necessary to have access to additional financial resources. Without additional funds, SBC can at best hope to maintain its existing standard of service. Even this may not be possible in the face of mounting inflationary pressures.

Column: 1513



    It is also SBC's intention to purchase better programmes which are educational, informative or of better cultural value. Such programmes will cost more to acquire because they are not usually available on the "bicycle circuit". Therefore, SBC would not be able to share the cost of such programmes with other TV stations in the region.

    SBC is a young organization. It is prudent to build up a reserve fund to cater for the future expansion of operation, improvement of quality, training and upgrading of manpower and any unforeseen circumstances. I mention the last point because advertising business is among the first to suffer from a cutback in expenditure in a recession.

    SBC's licence fees on TV and radio have remained unchanged for the past four years in spite of substantial increase in operating cost. As it stands now, the colour TV licence fee at $54, black and white TV licence fee at $36 and radio licence fee at $12, are already very low, considering that the licensee has available 13 hours of SBC TV programmes daily and 18 hours of radio programmes over each of the five radio channels.

    The revenue from radio and TV licences for the financial year 1980 amounted to $13 million or 20% of SBC annual income. A downward revision of licence fee will significantly affect the financial resources of SBC. To try to make good the loss of revenue by radio and TV commercials will mean that there will be far more commercial breaks interrupting programmes. This is not desirable. Moreover, not all of SBC's programmes are commercially exploitable.

    The overall audience response to changes and improvement made since the inception of SBC has been favourable. The momentum built up in improving its services will be lost if SBC's revenue were to be reduced. Hence, so long as SBC uses its surplus to improve the quality of programmes and the standard of services for the benefit of its viewers and listeners, no one should grudge paying the radio and TV licence fee.

Column: 1514



     Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): Mr Speaker, Sir, I believe the advertising rates of SBC are going up, Could the Minister give an indication of what is the estimated increase in revenue?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Sir, I am afraid I cannot give the hon. Member an estimate right now. The rates will go up from next month, which is the new financial year, and the full impact will be known by March 1983.

     Mr Hwang Soo Jin: Sir, if as a result of this increase and after a further period of 12 months, the surplus continues to accumulate, would the Minister then consider a reduction in licence fee?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Sir, I think that when we have a surplus we will have to consider the matter in the circumstances prevailing at that time. There is much scope for improvement in the SBC services. We are not using the surplus to pay dividends to anybody. Every cent generated will be used to provide a better service to Singapore.

If there was such a precedent or such a case, why can the HDB not give priority allocation of accommodation to employees going to be resettled by PSA which is also a statutory board?

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to ask a few questions of the Hon. Minister for National Development with regard to the fact that the HDB will be given a loan of $2.253 billion for FY 82, representing an increase of $789 million or 53.9% over FY 81 provision.

    Before I come to my question, I would like to draw the attention of the House to the remarks made by the Hon. Minister for Trade and Industry in his Budget Statement where it is stated:

    'Over this decade, the construction industry will figure even more in our economic plan because of the additional challenge it faces of having to build 290,000 new HDB flats for our population by 1990.'

    To my mind, the growth of the HDB with regard to the building of housing units in the years 1980 and 1981 had been rather slow, due to a variety of factors like shortage of labour, and building materials.

Column: 1517

Whilst the HDB has been able to overcome the latter problem, that is, building materials, it has still to come to grips and work out the question of labour. This brings me to the point of what the HDB intends to do to overcome the problem.

    According to the HDB Annual Report 1980-81, a record Government loan of $1.13 billion was given to the Board which represented 36% more than the year before, but despite this increase in loans, the number of housing units completed, as I was given to understand, was very much less. In this respect, with such a substantial increase in loan for FY 82, can the Hon. Minister elaborate on what would be the target of growth in the public housing programme for the coming fiscal year?

    I know that the HDB had in the latter half of last year been able to get contractors to come forward and accept big contracts so as to build more housing units. I think public housing deserves top priority over other pressing matters, as it is a programme to meet the housing needs of our people. While we take pride that about 70% of our population are now housed in HDB flats, I am sure a good number of new applicants have joined in the queue for more flats. Hence, the need to accelerate the housing programme in the 80s. May the Hon. Minister in reply also enlighten the House on upgrading skills in the construction industry, not only from the point of mechanization and automation, but also from the point of developing higher skills on the part of our construction workers, bearing in mind the fact that foreign workers will be phased out in years to come.

    Sir, can the HDB not also look into the question of providing more car parking lots in the new estates in their conceptual plans of housing estates, as the number of flat dwellers owning cars has definitely increased? For example, Punggol Estate, which has some 21 housing blocks, needs at least 200 more car parking lots.

    Finally, Sir, in accelerating the housing programme, can the Hon. Minister inform

Column: 1518

the House of the reduction in the waiting time for those who have applied for HDB flats?

     Mr Jeyaretnam rose -

     The Chairman: You have not filed any notice on this amendment.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, before I answer the points raised by the hon. Members for Khe Bong and Punggol, I would like to ask the Clerk of Parliament to circulate a Table (Cols. 1603 - 1604) showing the Income and Expenditure on Service and Conservancy of the HDB estates.
Table - INCOME AND EXPENDITURE ON SERVICE & CONSERVANCY (Cols. 1603 - 1604)


    Hon. Members of the House will see from the Table that the HDB had suffered a net deficit of $15.7 million on service and conservancy in the financial year 1979-80 and $48.2 million in the financial year 1980-81. This information was published in the February issue of the magazine Our Home. The details are in the magazine. The magazine is distributed free to all Housing Board residents.

    The hon. Member for Punggol is correct in pointing out that the HDB has been getting very big loans from the Government for the housing programme. I would like to provide the Member with the detailed information requested on the HDB programme. As at the end of last month, the HDB has a waiting list of a total of 113, 871 applicants, of which 14,348 are for rental flats and 99,523 for purchase flats. Between now and 1985, the HDB plans to complete 140,000 units of flats as follows.

    For this year, 1982, because of the rather slow start in the last two years, the HDB

Column: 1519

can only complete 19,500 units; 38,500 units next year; 40,000 units in 1984 and 42,000 units in 1985; making a total of 140,000 by 1985. Barring any unforeseen difficulties in the construction industry, all applicants on the waiting list can be offered a flat by 1985.

    The waiting period for future applicants is expected to be shorter as the HDB accelerates its building programme and the waiting list is steadily reduced.

    I shall now deal with the request by the hon. Member for Khe Bong about granting priority of HDB flats to the PSA workers. Under the Government's resettlement policy, the HDB is responsible for the clearance and relocation of the staff who are occupying quarters for the statutory authorities. But it depends on the status of the residents. If the residents are tenants of the quarters or accommodation, then they are not entitled to resettlement priority. I will just give an example. The HDB has several types of accommodation. We have, for example, a lot of bungalows in Kay Siang Road, formerly occupied by SIT senior staff. But after the formation of the HDB, no quarters are provided for the senior staff. These bungalows are being let out on monthly tenancies to various people. These HDB tenants who are living in Kay Siang Road bungalows are not entitled to alternative accommodation if they are asked to vacate the quarters by the HDB.

    Similarly, I understand that the Blair Plain residents, either PSA or non-PSA staff, are monthly tenants and therefore they are not entitled to resettlement benefits, i.e. they cannot be granted priority in the allocation of flats.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the Hon. Minister has not answered two of my questions. One is on the overall central planning of new estates. Can the HDB not look into the question of providing sufficient car parking lots? The second question is with regard to the upgrading of skills in the construction industry. How does the HDB propose to tackle this problem of upgrading the skills, taking into consideration mechanization and automation? The Minister has not replied to these two points.

Column: 1520



     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, regarding the increase of car parks in HDB estates, the HDB has a standard on the provision of car parks for various types of flats. From our experience, when an estate is occupied, in the beginning, the car parks are adequate. But subsequently as the owners of flats or tenants improve their economic situation, they start buying cars, then there is the complaint of the shortage of car parks. On the whole, there are more car parks in the HDB estates than cars. But the reason car owners. are complaining is that they are unable to park their cars in the particular car park, usually near their flats. The HDB works on the principle that if there are surplus car parks within the housing estate but are some distance away from the popular areas, then the HDB will not increase the car parks. The HDB will tell the residents, "If you cannot get parking lots in this particular car park, there are other car parks in the estate with vacant lots and you can apply for those lots." But if there are really not enough car parking lots, in other words, there are more cars than parking lots, then the HDB will consider providing additional car parks.

On this question of shortage of car parks in Punggol, I think I will ask the HDB to look into it, and we will base the request on the same principle. If there are really not enough car parks, we will provide more car parks.

    On the question of upgrading the skills of construction workers, HDB is at present providing interest-free loans to contractors to buy more machines in order to mechanize more processes in the construction industry. The second point is that HDB has awarded the "prefabrication" contract to foreign contractors, and we hope the foreign contractors will bring new construction techniques and new technology to Singapore to upgrade the construction industry.

    Another matter is that the HDB is undertaking the training of some of the

Column: 1521

national servicemen to be skilled construction workers. We are hoping that these people, after their national service, will eventually remain in the building industry to become skilled workers. Also, HDB together with other Government departments are at present considering the setting up of a school to train skilled workers. This is in the thinking stage at the moment.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head T be reduced by $10 in respect of Subhead TF-02 Object Group 1210 of the Main Estimates.

    In moving this amendment, I simply wish to find out from the Minister how long it takes for the Building Control Division to approve a building plan submitted by a developer?

     The Minister of State for National Development (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Sir, I am replying on behalf of my Minister. The hon. Member has asked how long it takes my Ministry to approve planning applications. This would depend on the nature of the application and the complexity of the case. But before going into that, perhaps I can explain what has happened because there have been some complaints about delays in planning approvals.

    In recent years the buoyant property market and the building boom have imposed severe strains on the processing of planning and building plan applications.

Column: 1522

The longer time that has been taken to process the applications for approval has been due to the following reasons:

    (1) An enormous increase in the number of new applications. The number of applications for the erection of new buildings doubled during the period 1978 to 1981.

    (2) The boom conditions in the private sector have led to a drain of experienced planners and technical officers to the private sector, making it more difficult to recruit such grades for the Government.

    (3) The boom conditions for private architects and engineers have led to staff shortages for the private sector also, resulting often in the submission of incomplete or inaccurate plans which require further processing by the Building Control Division.

    (4) In a situation where property transactions are rapid, new owners invariably want to change the approved plans of the previous owners. Even owners with approved plans often change their own plans to meet changing market conditions. All these result in abortive work for the Planning authority.

    Arising from the voluminous increase in planning applications, the Ministry has been reviewing procedures to expedite planning and building plan approvals. These include:

    (a) A new system of outline applications to enable developers to test their proposals against planning requirements and to have a quick reply. This sort of application may take sometimes two weeks for approval to be given. Based on the in-principle approval, the developer can ask for a determination of the development charge, which can therefore be given very quickly.

    (b) A new system to accept architect's and engineer's certification of plans as accurate with only random checking. This cuts down laborious and time-consuming checking work on. the part of the Building Control Division.

    (c) Early payment of development charge and re-zoning, as I have explained, to expedite the processing of planning approvals.

Column: 1523



    (d) Specific internal time limits for each processing stage to ensure that plans are speedily approved.

    With the streamlining of the processing procedure, the approval of plans is now much faster than before. The Ministry is looking into further areas where processing can be expedited.

    The expeditious approval of plans depends not only on various Government departments involved but also on the developers and their consultants. Numerous amendments and changes proposed by developers in processing mid-stream will delay project approval. Incorrect or incomplete submission of plans by consultants requiring the return of plans for correct submissions also leads to delay. Invariably consultants, pressured by clients, put the blame on Government departments when any delay occurs. In one case, for example, my Minister, reacting to a developer's complaint that his plans were delayed for 24 months, found on close investigation that for 17 months the plans were with the developer's consultants.

     Mr Tang See Chim (Chua Chu Kang): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head T be reduced by $10 in respect of Subhead TF-02 of the Main Estimates.

    Sir, the purpose of my moving this amendment is to draw the Minister's attention to two rather frequent and recurring complaints in the rural areas. These are the demolition of eaves that do not conform to building control requirements, and the demolition of R2 toilets built to the specification of the Ministry of the Environment. For some reason they do not seem to comply with the building control requirements.

    According to the present regulation of the Building Control Division, eaves must

Column: 1524

be of a certain width. However, this width does not seem to take account of the tropical sun and the tropical rain. Invariably, in the rural areas the rural folk would extend the eaves to a width that is consistent with what they think would shield them from the rain and the sun. I do not really know and perhaps the Minister could enlighten us: why is it that the width of the eaves should be so narrow that it does not shade the house from the rain and the sun?

    I was told sometime ago that our building regulations previously required roofs of houses to be at 450, and the explanation for this requirement was, so that the snow would not accumulate. I do not know whether it is really for this reason because in temperate countries the people like the sun and also there is not really too much torrential rain. Is it because of that that we require the eaves to be of a certain width? So far as the rural areas are concerned, these eaves are really not suitable for our climatic conditions. In any case the eaves of the houses which the Ministry seeks to demolish do not offend against aesthetics. They look beautiful and, as far as I can see, they really also do not endanger the structure of the building. So perhaps the Minister could consider this and allow the present buildings that have got these extended eaves to remain.

    The second point is the R2 lavatory system. Because of the catchment area in Chua Chu Kang, and I think the R2 system also applies to the other rural areas, the Ministry requires the residents in rural areas to install this particular sewerage system. So these toilets are built and passed the inspection of the Ministry of the Environment.
